editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: A Continuation of the Second part of the ENQUIRY Into the REASONS Offered by Sa. Oxon for the Abrogating of the TEST: relating to the Idolatry of the Church of Rome.
div.p: THe words of the Te≈øt, that belong to this point, are the≈øe, The Invocation or Adoration of the Virgin Mary, or any other Saint, and the Sacrifice of the Ma≈øs, as they are now u≈øed in the Church of Rome, are Super≈øtitious and Idolatrous: Upon which our Author fa≈øtens this Cen≈øure, that ≈øince by this the Church of Rome is charged with Idolatry, which both forfeits mens Lives here, and their Salvation hereafter, according to the expre≈øs words of Scripture, it is a damnable piece of Cruelty and Uncharitablene≈øs to load them with this charge, if they are not guilty of it: and upon this he goes to clear them of it, not only in the two Articles mentioned in the Te≈øt, the Worship of Saints, and the Sacrifice of the Ma≈øs, but that his Apology might be compleat, he takes in, and indeed In≈øi≈øts chiefly, on the Worship of Images, tho that is not at all mentioned in the Te≈øt. He brings a great many quotations out of the Old Te≈øtament, to shew the Idolatry prohibited in it, was the Worshipping the Sun, Moon and Stars, or the making an Image to re≈øemble the Divine E≈ø≈øence, upon which he produces al≈øo ≈øome other Authorities: And in this con≈øi≈øts the ≈øub≈øtance of his Plea for the Church of Rome.

But upon all this he ought to have retracted both the Licen≈øe that him≈øelf gave ≈øome years ago, to Dr. Stillingfleets Book Of the Idolatry of the Church of Rome, and his own ha≈øty a≈ø≈øertion in condemning both Turk and Papi≈øt as guilty of Idolatry; the one for worshipping a leud Impo≈øtor, and the other for Worshipping a ≈øen≈øele≈øs piece of matter. Def. of his Eccl. Pol. p. 285, 286. It ≈øeems he is now convinced, that the latter part of this charge that falls on the Papi≈øts, was as fal≈øe, as the former that falls on the Turks certainly is; for they never Worshipped Mahomet, but hold him only in high Reverence, as an Extraordinary Prophet, as the Jews do Mo≈øes. It is very like that if the Turks had taken Vienna, he would have retracted that, as he has now in effect done the other: for I believe he is in the ≈øame di≈øpo≈øition to reconcile him≈øelf to the Mufti, and the Pope: but the Ottoman Empire is now as low as Popery is high: ≈øo he will brave the Turk ≈øtill to his teeth, tho he did him wrong, and will humble him≈øelf to the Papi≈øt, tho he did him nothing but right: but now I take leave of the man, and will confine my ≈øelf ≈øeverely to the matter that is before me; And.

I. How guilty ≈øoever the Church of Rome is of Idolatry, yet the Te≈øt does not plainly a≈ø≈øert that: for there is as great a difference between Idolatrous and Idolatry, as there is in Law between what is Trea≈øonable and what is Trea≈øon. The one Imports only a Worship that is conformable to Idolatry, and that has a tendency to it: wheras the other is the plain ≈øin it ≈øelf; there is al≈øo a great difference, between what is now u≈øed in that Church, and the Explanations that ≈øome of their Doctors give of that u≈øage. We are to take the u≈øage of the Church of Rome from her Publick Offices, and her authori≈øed practices; ≈øo that if the≈øe have a Conformity

to Idolatry, and a tendency to it, then the words of the Te≈øt are ju≈øtified, what ≈øen≈øe ≈øoever ≈øome learned men among them may put on the≈øe Offices and Practices; therfore the Te≈øt may be well maintained, even tho we should acknowledg that the Church of Rome was not guilty of Idolatry.

II. If Idolatry was a Crime punishable by Death under the Old Te≈øtament, that does not at all concern us: nor does the Charge of Idolatry authori≈øe the people to kill all Idolaters: unle≈øs our Author can prove, that we believe our ≈øelves to be under all the Political and Judiciary Precepts of the Law of Mo≈øes: and even among the Jews the execution of that ≈øevere Law, belonged either to the Magi≈øtrate, or to ≈øome authori≈øed and In≈øpired per≈øon, who as a Zealot might execute the Law, when the Magi≈øtrate was wanting to his duty. So that this was writ Invidiou≈øly, only as it ≈øeems to Inflame the Papi≈øts the more again≈øt us. But the ≈øame Calvini≈øt Prince, that has expre≈ø≈øed ≈øo ju≈øt an aver≈øion to the repealing the Te≈øt, has at the ≈øame time shewed ≈øo mercifull an Inclination towards the Ro. Catholicks, that of all the Reproaches in the World, one that intended to plead for that Religion ought to have avoided the mentioning of Blood or Cruelty with the greate≈øt care.

III. It is true, we cannot help believing that Idolatry is a damnable ≈øin, that shuts men out of the Kingdom of Heaven: and if every ≈øin in which a man dies without repentance, does it, much more this, which is one of the greate≈øt of all ≈øins. But yet after all, there is Mercy for Sins of Ignorance, upon mens general repentance; and therefore ≈øince God alone knows the degrees of mens knowledge and of their Ignorance, and how far it is either Affected on the one hand, or Invincible on the other; we do not take upon us to enter into Gods Secrets, or to Judg of the Salvation or Damnation of particular per≈øons; nor mu≈øt we be bya≈ø≈øed in our Enquiry into the nature of any ≈øin, either by a fond regard to the ≈øtate of our Ance≈øtors, or by the due re≈øpect that we owe to tho≈øe who are over us in Civil matters. In this ca≈øe things are what God has declared them to be: We can neither make them better nor wor≈øe than he has made them: and we are only to Judge of things, leaving per≈øons to the merciful as well as the ju≈øt and dreadful judgment of God.

IV. All the ≈øtir that our Author keeps with the examining of the Idolatry committed by the Jews, under the Old Te≈øtament, ≈øuppo≈øing it were all true, will ≈øerve no more for acquitting the Church of Rome, than a Plea would avail a Criminal, who were arraigned of high Trea≈øon for Coyning Money or for Counterfeiting the Kings Seal, in which one should ≈øet forth that High Trea≈øon was the Murdering the King, or the levying war again≈øt him, and that therefore the Criminal who was guilty of neither of the≈øe two, ought to be acquitted. Idolatry as well as Trea≈øon is a Comprehen≈øive Notion, and has many different branches: ≈øo that tho the Worshipping the Ho≈øt of heaven, or the Worshipping an Image as a re≈øemblance of the Divinity, may be acknowledged to be the highe≈øt degrees of Idolatry, yet many other corruptions in the Worship of God are ju≈øtly reducible ro it, and may be termed not only Idolatrous but Idolatry it ≈øelf.

V. Our Saviour in his ≈øermon on the Mount has shewed us how many ≈øins are reducible to the ≈øecond Table of the Law, be≈øides tho≈øe of Murder, Adultery, &c. that are expre≈øly named in it: and tho the Jews in that time having delivered them≈øelves entirely from the ≈øin of Idolatry, to which their Fathers were ≈øo prone, gave him no occa≈øion of commenting on the fir≈øt and ≈øecond Commandment, yet by the parity of things we may conclude, that many ≈øins are reducible to them, be≈øides tho≈øe that are expre≈ø≈øely named. And tho we have not ≈øo compleat a Hi≈øtory of the Idolatry of the Neighbouring Nations to Iudea, before the Captivity, yet we do certainly know what was the Idolatry of which the Greeks and Romans were guilty when the New Te≈øtament was writ. And tho the greate≈øt part of the New Te≈øtament is written chiefly with relation to the Jews, who≈øe freedom from Idolatry gave no occa≈øion to

made plainer than the matter of Fact is. We know likewi≈øe, that when the Controver≈øy aro≈øe concerning the Godhead of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, Athana≈øius and the other Fathers, made u≈øe of the ≈øame Argument again≈øt the Arrians, who worshipped him; that they could not be excu≈øed from the ≈øin of Idolatry, in worshipping and Invocating him, whom they believed to be only a Creature: which shews, that it was the ≈øen≈øe of the Chri≈øtians of that Age, that all Acts of Divine worship, and in particular, all Prayers that were offered up to any that was not truely and by nature God, and the Eternal God, were ≈øo many Acts of Idolatry. So that upon the whole matter, it is clear, that the worshipping the true God under a Corporeal Repre≈øentation, and the worshipping or Invocating of Creatures, tho in an Inferiour degree, was taxed by the Apo≈øtles and by the Primitive Church as Idolatrous. When they accu≈øe them for tho≈øe Corruptions of Divine worship, they did not con≈øider the ≈øoftning excu≈øes of more refined men, ≈øo much as the acts that were done, which to be ≈øure do always carry the ≈øtupid Vulgar to the gro≈ø≈øe≈øt degrees of Idolatry: and thetefore every ≈øtep towards it is ≈øo ≈øeverely forbid by God: ≈øince upon one ≈øtep made in the publick worship, the people are ≈øure to make a great many more in their notions of things. Therefore if we should accu≈øe the Church of Rome, for all the exce≈ø≈øes of the pa≈øt Ages, or of the more Ignorant Nations in the pre≈øent Age, ≈øuch as Spain and Portugal, even this might be in ≈øome degree well grounded; becau≈øe the publick and authori≈øed Offices and Practices of that Church, has given the ri≈øe to all tho≈øe Di≈øorders: and even in this, we should but Copy after the Fathers, who always repre≈øent the Pagan Idolatry not as Cicero or Plutarch had done it, but according to the gro≈ø≈øe≈øt notions and practices of the Vulgar.

XIV. All that our Author ≈øays, concerning the Cherubims, de≈øerves not an an≈øwer: for what u≈øe ≈øoever might be made of this, to excu≈øe the Lutherans, for the u≈øe of Images, without worshipping them (tho after all the doing ≈øuch a thing upon a Divine Command, and the doing it without a Command, are two very different things,) yet it cannot belong to the worship of Images, ≈øince the I≈øraelites payed no worship to the Cherubims. They pay'd indeed a Divine worship to the Cloud of Glory, which was between them, and which is often in the Old Te≈øtament called God him≈øelf, in all tho≈øe expre≈ø≈øions, in which he is ≈øaid to dwell between the Cherubims. But this being a miraculous Symbol ‚Ä¢ of the Divine pre≈øence, from which they had an≈øwers in all extraordinary ca≈øes, it was God him≈øelf, without any Image or Repre≈øentation, that was worshipped in it. As we Chri≈øtians, pay our Adorations to the Humane Nature of Chri≈øt, by vertue of that more ≈øublime and ineffable indwelling of the Godhead in Him: in which ca≈øe it is God only that we worship, in the man Chri≈øt. Even as the re≈øpect that we pay to a man terminates in his mind, tho the outward expre≈ø≈øions of it go to the body, to which the mind is united. So in that unconceivable Union between the Divine and Humane Natures in Chri≈øt, we adore the Godh ‚Ä¢ ad only, even when we worship the man.

XV. The General part of this Di≈øcour≈øe, being thus ≈øtated, the application of it to the Church of Rome, will be no hard matter. I will not in≈øi≈øt much on the Article of Image Worship, becau≈øe it is not comprehended in the Te≈øt, tho our Author dwells longe≈øt on it, to let us ≈øee how carefully, but to how little purpo≈øe he had read Dr. Spencers learned Book. But if one con≈øiders the Ceremonies and Prayers with which Images, and particularly Cro≈ø≈øes, are to be dedicated by the Roman Pontifical, and the formal Adoration of the Cro≈øs on Good Fryday, and the ≈øtrange vertues that are not only believed to be in ≈øome Images by the rabble, but that are authori≈øed not only by the Books of Devotion publickly allowed among them, but even by Papal Bulls and Indulgences, he will be forced to confe≈øs, that the old notions of the Teraphim are clearly revived among them. This could be made out in an infinite Induction of particulars, of which the Reader will find a large account in the learned Dr. Brevint's Treati≈øe, entitled, Saul and Samuel at Endor. But I come now to the two Branches mentioned in the Te≈øt.

XVI. One is the Sacrifice of the Ma≈øs, in which if either our Sen≈øes, that tell us, it is now Bread and Wine, or the New Te≈øtament in which it is called both Bread and the fruit of the Vine, even after the Con≈øecration, or if the Opinion of the fir≈øt ≈øeven Centuries, or if the true principles of Philo≈øophy, concurring altogether, are ≈øtrong enough, we are as certain as it is po≈ø≈øible for us to be of any thing, that they are ≈øtill according to our Authors own phra≈øe, a ≈øencele≈øs piece of matter. When therefore this has divine Adoration offered to it, when it is called, the good God, carried about in ≈øolemn Proce≈ø≈øions, and receives as publick and as humble a Veneration, as ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ uld be offered up to the Deity it ≈øelf, i ‚Ä¢ it appeared vi≈øibly: here the highe≈øt degree of Divine worship is offered up to a Creature: nor will ≈øuch
Worshippers, believing this to be truely the Body of Chri≈øt, ≈øave the matter, if indeed it is not ≈øo. This may no doubt go a great way to ≈øave them≈øelves, and to bring their ≈øin into the the cla≈øs of the ≈øins of Ignorance: but what large thoughts ≈øoever we may have of the mercies of God to their per≈øons, we can have no Indulgence for an Act of Divine Adoration, which is directed to an Object that we are either ≈øure is Bread, or we are ≈øure of nothing el≈øe.

XVII. As for the Invocation and Adoration of the B. Virgin and the Saints, I shall offer only three Cla≈ø≈øes of In≈øtances to prove it Idolatrous. 1. In the Office of the Ma≈øs on many of the Saints days, that Sacrifice, which is no other than the Body and Blood of Chri≈øt, according to them, is offered up to the honour of the Saints, and they pray to God, to accept of it thro the Saints Interce≈ø≈øion. One would think, it were enough to offer up the Sacrifices of prayers and prai≈øes to them: but here is a Sacrifice, which carries in the plain words of it, the mo≈øt ab≈øurd Idolatry that is po≈ø≈øible; which is the offering up the Creator to the honour of a Creature.

2. In the Prayers and Hymns that are in their publick Offices, there are Petitions offered up to the Saints, that in the plain ≈øen≈øe of the words import their pardoning our ≈øins, and changing our hearts. The daily prayer to the Virgin goes far this way: Tu nos ab ho≈øte protege, & hora mortis ≈øu≈øcipe: Do thou protect us from our Enemy, and receive us in the hour of death. Another goes yet further: Culpas no≈øtras ablue, ut perennis ≈øedem gloriae, per te redempti, valeamus ≈øcandere: Wash thou away our ≈øins, that ≈øo being redeemed by thee, we may a≈øcend up to the man≈øions of glory. That to the Angels is of the ≈øame nature, No≈øtra diluant jam peccata prae≈øtando ≈øupernam Coeli gloriam: May they wash away our ≈øins, and grant us the heavenly glory. I shall to this add two Addre≈ø≈øes to two of our English Saints; the fir≈øt is to St. Alban, Te nunc petimus Patrone praeco ≈øedule, qui es no≈øtra vera gloria, ≈øolve precum votis, ≈øervorum ≈øcelera: We implore thee, our Patron, who art our true Glory, do thou take away the crimes of thy Servants, by thy prayers. And the other relates to Thomas Becket, whom I believe, our Author will not deny to have been as great a Rebel, as either Coligny, or his Faction; and yet they pray thus to Chri≈øt, Tu per Thomae ≈øanguinem, quem pro te effudit, fac nos Chri≈øte ≈øcandere quo Thomas a≈øcendit. Do thou, O Chri≈øt, make us by the blood of Thomas, which he shed for thee, to a≈øcend up whether he has a≈øcended: and the Hymn upon him, is that Ver≈øe of the eighth P≈øalm, Thou ha≈øt crowned him with Glory and Honour, and has ≈øet him over all the works of thy hands. One would think, it were no bold thing to pronounce all this, and innumerable more In≈øtances, which might be brought to the ≈øame purpo≈øe, to be Idolatrous. If we are ≈øent by our Author to the ≈øen≈øes that may be put on the≈øe words, I shall only ≈øay with relation to that, that the Te≈øt condemns the Devotions as they are u≈øed in the Roman Church: ≈øo this belongs to the plain ≈øen≈øe of the words, and if it is confe≈ø≈øed that the≈øe are Idolatrous, as a≈øcribing to Creatures the right of pardoning ≈øin, and of opening the Kingdom of Heaven, which are main parts of the Divine glory, then the matter of the Te≈øt is ju≈øtified.

A third ≈øort of In≈øtance is in the prayer that comes after the Prie≈øt has pronounced the words of Ab≈øolution, Pa≈ø≈øio Domini no≈øtri Je≈øu Chri≈øti, merita B. Mariae Virginis, & omnium Sanctorum, & quicquid boni feceris, vel mali ≈øu≈øtinueris, ≈øint tibi in remi≈ø≈øionem peccatorum, augmentum gratiae, & premium vitae aeternae: May the Pa≈ø≈øion of our Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt, the merits of the B. Virgin, and all the Saints, and all the good thou ha≈øt done, or the evil that thou ha≈øt ≈øuffered, be to thee effectual, for the remi≈ø≈øion of thy ≈øins, the encrea≈øe of grace, and the reward of Eternal life. Ab≈øolution in its true and un≈øophi≈øticated meaning, being the declaration made to a Penitent of the mercys of God in Chri≈øt, according to the Go≈øpel, I would gladly know, what milder Cen≈øure is due to the mixing the merits of the Virgin and the Saints, with the Pa≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øt, in order to the obtaining this Go≈øpel pardon, with all the effects of it, than this of our Te≈øt, that it is Idolatrous.

I have now examined the two points, in which our Author thought fit to make an Apology for the Church of Rome, without de≈øcending to the particulars of his Plea more minutely. I have u≈øed him in this more gently than he de≈øerves: for as I examined his Rea≈øonings, I found all along both ≈øo much Ignorance, and ≈øuch gro≈øs disingenuity, that I had ≈øome difficulty to re≈øtrain my ≈øelf, from flying out on many occa≈øions: but I re≈øolved to pur≈øue the≈øe two points, with the gravity of ≈øtile which the matter required, without entangling the di≈øcour≈øe, with ≈øuch unplea≈øant digre≈ø≈øions, as the di≈øcovery of his Errors might have led me to. And I thought it enough to free unwary Readers from the mi≈øtakes into which his Book might lead them, without encrea≈øing the contempt belonging to the Writer, who has now enough upon him; but I pray, God grant him Repentance and a better mind.
